kill.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to make a person or animal die
kill.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Why did she kill her husband?
Murray held a gun to his head and threatened to kill him.
Four people were killed when a train plunged into a flooded river.
kill.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to make something stop operating or fail
kill.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Joe pulled in and killed the engine.
The out-of-town shopping centre will kill local trade.
kill.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to be very angry with someone
kill.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Mom will kill me if I’m late.
kill.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to make someone feel annoyed, sad, concerned etc
kill.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: What happened next? The suspense is killing me.
It kills me to see him working so hard.
it kills somebody to do something
kill.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to make someone laugh a lot
kill.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: They weren’t bothered – in fact, they were killing themselves laughing.
kill.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: kill
to make someone die
The driver and his passenger were killed in the crash.
He was killed by rival gang members.
murder
to deliberately kill someone – used when talking about this as a crime
He was convicted of murdering his wife.
commit manslaughter
to kill someone without intending to – used when talking about this as a crime
The court ruled that the guard had committed manslaughter.
assassinate
to deliberately kill an important person, especially a politician
He was part of a plot to assassinate Hitler.
slay
to kill someone or something in a violent way – used in newspaper reports and also in old stories
Two teenagers were slain in the shootings.
St. George slew the dragon.
The king was slain at the battle of Hastings.
execute
to kill someone as a punishment for a crime
McVeigh, who killed 168 people in a bombing attack, was executed by lethal injection.
eliminate
to kill someone in order to prevent them from causing trouble
a ruthless dictator who eliminated all his rivals
take somebody out
to kill someone in order to get rid of them, especially an enemy or someone who is causing trouble for you
US forces used air strikes to take out the enemy positions.
One of the other drug dealers may have decided to take him out.
bump somebody off
He was so irritating I felt like bumping him off myself.
do away with somebody
The settlers in Jamestown had been done away with, but no one knew how.
to kill yourself
commit suicide
to kill yourself
He committed suicide after the death of his girlfriend.
take your own life
to kill yourself
He had taken his own life while he was severely depressed.
They believe that it is a sin to take your own life.
to kill a large number of people
massacre
to kill a large number of people in a violent way
Thousands of peaceful demonstrators were massacred by the soldiers.
slaughter
to kill a large number of people in a violent way. Slaughter is also used about killing animals for food
The army slaughtered thousands of civilians in an effort to stop the revolt.
The pigs were slaughtered on the farm.
exterminate
to kill large numbers of a particular group, so that they no longer exist
Hitler’s goal was to exterminate the Jews.
kill.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the act of killing a hunted animal
kill.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He raised his knife for the kill.
kill.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an animal that is killed by another animal
kill.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The cubs will share the remains of the kill.
kill.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if someone kills an idea, product etc, they decide to stop developing it, selling it etc
kill.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: They have killed plans for a weekly regional magazine in Los Angeles.
